body: What do  isSystemColumn() and  isSysKeyColumn() methods return? It looks like isSaltColumn_ is not set other than when it comes via constructor.

isSystemColumn() should return whether the column is visible when doing a select *. isSysKeyColumn() should return whether this is the SYSKEY system column. In some cases these methods (especially isSaltColumn() and isDivisioningColumn()) may not return TRUE if we are looking at an alternate index, because such indexes just contain the primary key columns. These columns in the index do not always indicate actual salting or divisioning of the index.

Example:

```
create unique index ix1 on t(a);          -- may contain a _SALT_ column, index is not salted
create index ix2 on t(a) salt like table; -- also contains a _SALT_ column, this one is salted
```

Sorry, I'm not sure whether this is an issue in this particular case.
Looks good to me, thanks for fixing that!

Actually, at second thought: Could we separate the mk.sh and cp commands into two lines and just ignore the exit code of cp? It would be good to catch checkins that break the GUI build. We had that a while ago and had a hard time getting it back to work when we didn't notice the problem immediately.

Just curious, is this a bug in sem_open? I'm having a hard time imagining why we should have to initialize this buffer. The man page for sem_open says it expects a null-terminated string. Anyway, initializing it doesn't do any harm, so I'm just asking, not complaining.
@zellerh yes, that thought had occurred to me as well to make it into two lines. But you make a good point why that is necessary.  Will do.

yes, Hans, I think it again. You are quite right. This change doesn't make too much sense. The const string should contain a null at the end, and after that null, there will be some garbage. 
But when we test on CentOS, sqstart can never work well, monitor abort() exactly at this sem_open place, and if return value is SEM_FAILED, it will abort and Trafodion cannot start.
After make this change, rebuild and reinstall, sqstart works fine on CentOS 7. 
Maybe some change in libc in CentOS 7. Let me investigate it further. But this change does no harm, just may not properly fix the JIRA. I need to do more tests.
Is this change ready to commit?
It is ready to commit from code changes pov. Code has been merged with latest branch and contains the needed functionality.

A very big piece of work! Thanks very much for doing this, it's a big step forward in achieving our goals for the next release. I noted some smaller comments, but didn't review all the Java changes in detail, hopefully someone more familiar with T-Rex and HBase can do that.

Thanks for the explanation. Could it be some security problem or some left-over semaphore that causes the problem - but of course that would not explain why your change fixed the problem.

If this fixes the problem, then maybe the best thing is not to ask too many questions :-)

If this does not fix the problem, we will find out sooner or later and can investigate further. So, I see no harm in committing the change and seeing what happens.
Too much changes, it is very hard for me to so may changes. It may need Ma, Shengchen to explain it in some way about the basic idea of this change.
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?

Looks very good for me. 
This not only help for CentOS 7, but also other Linux dist in the future. We should reduce unnecessary dependencies as much as possible.

to Dave: yes, let me first do more investigation to find a better solution, this is not a very urgent requirement. 
to Selva: inside this method, isSystemColumn() and others all return false, it is where NAColumn object created that not properly set these flags. I am trying to find the root.
to Hans: RI is in a different code path I think, I am still trying to understand it. The predicate to ensure RI is generated by compiler, not from the source sql, so there must be some problem in the code which generate the original column list to compare.

hi, all,
Please don't merge this. I realize what Hans gut is quite right. 
I may made some fundamental mistakes here about how Trafodion support CentOS 7.
Our code is built in CentOS 6.5 , with lower version of libpthread . And when run on CentOS 7, it may behave in unexpected way. I guess what ever statement I add before sem_open() will fix the issue.
So correct way to support Trafodion running on CentOS 7 is to build Trafodion from a CentOS 7 system. 
My 'fix' to this issue is wrong. I will cancel this pull request.

The rework looks good to me.
Looks good to me, too, thanks for making that change.

I have run several times of YCSB tests, observed memory leak, it took me long time to track it down, and I found one serious problem in YCSB's code, look into all the test cases in YCSBWorkload2.java, all PreparedStatement instances it creates are never closed even when the statement execution is done, this causes serious memory leak, until the connection is closed or the process exits.
Previously, the PreparedStatement does not actually have batch ability, so the memory cost is very slow, but if you run statements without close again and again, as long as the time last long enough, along with more and more un-closed statements stay in, I can also observe the memory leak, just the growing rate is slightly enough cause no serious problem. I believe if it runs long enough this way, memory will be eventually exhausted.
With the new driver, because of the rowsets functions have much higher memory cost, the growing rate is much higher as well. But if we close the PreparedStatement every time once it's execution is done, I don't observe leak then.

I think the YCSB codes must be updated, make sure the PreparedStatement instances are closed once they are done with their job. Driver does not manage to close the PreparedStatement, because  we never know when the user will use this statement again, it's one time prepared, N times execution statement.

The attached screenshot is one example of the un-closed PreparedStatenent code in YCSBWorkload2.java
![31e7 tm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7919914/13523485/b439bf94-e230-11e5-826a-3cb1ad08a941.png)

.Is the Singletonselect_stmt set to NULL everytime after execution. If not, isn't the statement is prepared once and executed many times. I believe YCSB test is designed to prepare once and execute many times. if the preparedStatement is a IUD statement, all the memory allocated at the time of execution should be re-used everytime. In case of Select statement, the application can choose to call ResultSet.close().  If you close a prepareStatement, it is expected that the statement is prepared again.  

Yes. PreparedStatement is kept around till the connection is closed or till the user application explicitly closes the statement. YCSB wants to keep the statement around till the connection is closed. YCSB tests are not designed to prepare the statement everytime, because the execution time is very short. It is prepare once and execute many times kind of test.

A well written driver, should protect itself even if the application doesn't close the Resultset explicitly. It should trigger resource allocation when the ResultSet close object goes out of scope and gets garbage collected. This holds good for Statement or PreparedStatement also. Trafodion driver is supposed to create weak references and poll the associated reference queue for deallocating the resources when the object has no other reference. However, that may not be relevant here, because YCSB tests are designed to prepare once and execute many times.

You can test it with T4 driver and check if there is growth in mxosrvr memory similar to T2.

What if on my network I have a node called "Node1.amanda.com" and "node1.amanda.com"? If the monitor changes everything to lowercase then wouldn't there be confusion?

Maybe this isn't really an issue, but it came to my mind.

OK so tell me if this change is correct and is better:
replace: if (nac &&  nac->getDefaultValue() && strcmp(nac->getDefaultValue(),"NULL") != 0)

by: if (nac && nac-> getDefaultClass() != COM_NO_DEFAULT &&
nac->getDefaultClass() != COM_ALWAYS_COMPUTE_COMPUTED_COLUMN_DEFAULT &&
nac->getDefaultClass() != COM_ALWAYS_DEFAULT_COMPUTED_COLUMN_DEFAULT &&
nac->getDefaultClass() != COM_NULL_DEFAULT)

or probably using a switch construct with same semantic...

I think the exact replacement of the existing code will be (nac && nac->getDefaultValue() && (nac->getDefaultClass() != COM_NULL_DEFAULT).

Returns TRUE for any column with the default value but with non-null default value. This is what I understood reading the code before. For anything else it would be false. 

You can add nac->getDefaultClass() != COM_NULL_DEFAULT && nac->getDefaultClass() != COM_CURRENT_DEFAULT() because the columns with current default will be in hbase table always even when the column is omitted.
